div1.p: Hench requests details about the infected-clothing building experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Robert P. Cooke, September 6, 1940
div1.opener:
September 6, 1940
Dr. R. P. Cooke
State Department of Health
Lexington-Rockbridge Health Department
Lexington, Virginia
My dear Doctor Cooke:
div1.p:
I am delighted to hear from you, and I am so pleased that you were
willing to give me further information. I find that the very few copies of my mem-
orandum which I had typed are exhausted, since I sent one to Moran, and to two others
concerned in Havana, one to General Kean and one to General Truby. I expect one of
those back shortly and will hasten to send it to you, as I am most anxious to have
your comments after reading it. With it, I will send you a number of photographs,
old and new, and will take the liberty of asking you certain questions, hoping that
you can give me specific answers.

I think you are entirely too modest regarding the part you played.
When you volunteered to spend three weeks in the Infected Clothing Building, as far
as you and the world were concerned, you were accepting probable death. Nobody knew
for sure that infected clothing was not the source of yellow fever, and the world
will see fit to appraise your actions at a higher value than you so modestly have.

In the meantime, until you receive my memorandum, I would appreciate
it greatly if you would write down three or four or more pages, in as much detail as
you wish, regarding your own experiences. I should love to quote these directly in
my talk. I am anxious to have your confirmation as to the two volunteers who spent the
first period with you in the Infected Clothing Building, and a little more specific
information as to just how you handled these volunteers. I understand you slept in
the building at night after unpacking the infected clothing and bedding. Were these
hung around the walls, or in just what manner? It was Moran's impression that you more
or less occupied an adjacent tent during the day. Did you eat meals with the regular
group or were your meals brought to you? Any possible details regarding your experiences
I would be most grateful to have, and I can assure you that they will be used with dig-
nity and to your entire satisfaction, and that before I publish a single line, you
will have the opportunity to see and criticize my remarks.
div1.closer: Most sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
